elements.headline: a
elements.description: The HTML <a> element (or anchor element) creates a hyperlink to other web pages, files, locations within the same page, email addresses, or any other URL. MDN web docs: <a>: The Anchor element
elements.example:
Link to Named Anchor
Named Anchor

elements.headline: abbr
elements.description: The HTML Abbreviation element(<abbr>) represents an abbreviation or acronym; the optional title attribute can provide an expansion or description for the abbreviation. If present, title must contain this full description and nothing else. MDN web docs: <abbr>: The Abbreviation element
elements.example: Using <abbr title="HyperText Markup Language">HTML</abbr> is fun and easy!

elements.headline: address
elements.description: The HTML <address> element indicates that the enclosed HTML provides contact information for a person or people, or for an organization. MDN web docs: <address>: The Contact Address element
elements.example: <address>Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua.</address>

elements.headline: article
elements.description: The HTML <article> element represents a self-contained composition in a document, page, application, or site, which is intended to be independently distributable or reusable (e.g., in syndication). Examples include: a forum post, a magazine or newspaper article, or a blog entry. MDN web docs: <article>: The Contact Address element
elements.example: <article>Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua.</article>

elements.headline: aside
elements.description: The HTML <aside> element represents a portion of a document whose content is only indirectly related to the document's main content. Asides are frequently presented as sidebars or call-out boxes. MDN web docs: <aside>: The Aside element
elements.example: <aside>Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua.</aside>

elements.headline: audio
elements.description: The HTML <audio> element is used to embed sound content in documents. It may contain one or more audio sources, represented using the src attribute or the <source> element: the browser will choose the most suitable one. It can also be the destination for streamed media, using a MediaStream. MDN web docs: <audio>: The Embed Audio element

elements.headline: b
elements.description: The HTML Bring Attention To element (<b>)  is used to draw the reader's attention to the element's contents, which are not otherwise granted special importance. This was formerly known as the Boldface element, and most browsers still draw the text in boldface. However, you should not use <b> for styling text; instead, you should use the CSS font-weight property to create boldface text, or the <strong> element to indicate that text is of special importance. MDN web docs: <b>: The Bring Attention To element
elements.example: This article describes several text-level elements.

elements.headline: bdi
elements.description:
The HTML Bidirectional Isolate element (<bdi>)  tells the browser's bidirectional algorithm to treat the text it contains in isolation from its surrounding text. It's particularly useful when a website dynamically inserts some text and doesn't know the directionality of the text being inserted.

MDN web docs: <bdi>: The Bidirectional Isolate element
elements.example:
اَلأَعْشَى - 1st place
Jerry Cruncher - 2nd place

elements.headline: bdo
elements.description: The HTML Bidirectional Text Override element (<bdo>) overrides the current directionality of text, so that the text within is rendered in a different direction.MDN web docs: <bdo>: The Bidirectional Text Override element
elements.example:
This text will go left to right.

This text will go right to left.

elements.headline: blockquote
elements.description: The HTML <blockquote> Element (or HTML Block Quotation Element) indicates that the enclosed text is an extended quotation. Usually, this is rendered visually by indentation. A URL for the source of the quotation may be given using the cite attribute, while a text representation of the source can be given using the <cite> element. MDN web docs: <blockquote>: The Block Quotation element
elements.example: Avian carriers can provide high delay, low throughput, and low altitude service. The connection topology is limited to a single point-to-point path for each carrier, used with standard carriers, but many carriers can be used without significant interference with each other, outside of early spring. This is because of the 3D ether space available to the carriers, in contrast to the 1D ether used by IEEE802.3. The carriers have an intrinsic collision avoidance system, which increases availability.

elements.headline: br
elements.description: The HTML <br> element produces a line break in text (carriage-return). It is useful for writing a poem or an address, where the division of lines is significant. MDN web docs: <br>: The Line Break element
elements.example:
Mozilla
331 E. Evelyn Avenue
Mountain View, CA
94041
USA

elements.headline: button
elements.description: The HTML <button> element represents a clickable button, which can be used in forms or anywhere in a document that needs simple, standard button functionality. By default, HTML buttons are typically presented in a style similar to that of the host platform the user agent is running on, but you can change the appearance of the button using CSS. MDN web docs: <button>: The Button element
elements.example:
<!-- type: button --><button>Button</button>

<!-- type: submit -->
<button type="submit">Submit</button>

<!-- type: reset -->
<button type="reset">Reset</button>

elements.headline: cite
elements.description: The HTML Citation element (<cite>) is used to describe a reference to a cited creative work, and must include the title of that work. The reference may be in an abbreviated form according to context-appropriate conventions related to citation metadata. MDN web docs: <cite>: The Citation element
elements.example: More information can be found in <cite>[ISO-0000]</cite>.

elements.headline: code
elements.description: The HTML <code> element displays its contents styled in a fashion intended to indicate that the text is a short fragment of computer code. By default, the content text is displayed using the user agent's default monospace font. MDN web docs: <code>: The Inline Code element
elements.example: The function selectAll() highlights all the text in the input field so the user can, for example, copy or delete the text.

elements.headline: data
elements.description: The HTML <data> element links a given content with a machine-readable translation. If the content is time- or date-related, the <time> element must be used. MDN web docs: <data>: The Machine-Readable data element
elements.example:
New Products

  • Mini Ketchup
  • Jumbo Ketchup
  • Mega Jumbo Ketchup

elements.headline: del
elements.description: The HTML <del> element represents a range of text that has been deleted from a document. This can be used when rendering "track changes" or source code diff information, for example. The <ins> element can be used for the opposite purpose: to indicate text that has been added to the document. MDN web docs: <del>: The Deleted Text data element
elements.example: This text has been deleted, here is the rest of the paragraph.

elements.headline: dfn
elements.description: The HTML Definition element (<dfn>) is used to indicate the term being defined within the context of a definition phrase or sentence. The <p> element, the <dt>/<dd> pairing, or the <section> element which is the nearest ancestor of the <dfn> is considered to be the definition of the term. MDN web docs: <dfn>: The Definition element
elements.example:
The HTML Definition element (<dfn>) is used to indicate the term being defined within the context of a definition phrase or sentence.

The HST is among the most productive scientific instruments ever constructed.

elements.headline: div
elements.description: The HTML Content Division element (<div>) is the generic container for flow content. It has no effect on the content or layout until styled using CSS. MDN web docs: <div>: The Content Division element
elements.example: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua.

elements.headline: dl
elements.description: The HTML <dl> element represents a description list. The element encloses a list of groups of terms (specified using the <dt> element) and descriptions (provided by <dd> elements). Common uses for this element are to implement a glossary or to display metadata (a list of key-value pairs). MDN web docs: <dl>: The Description List element
elements.example:
<dl>
	<dt>Names</dt>
	<dt>Nicknames</dt>
	<dd>The King of the Monsters</dd>
	<dd>Gigantis</dd>
	<dd>Godzilla</dd>
	<dt>Born</dt>
	<dd>1952</dd>
	<dt>Birthplace</dt>
	<dd>Japan</dd>
	<dt>Color</dt>
	<dd>Green</dd>
</dl>

elements.headline: em
elements.description: The HTML <em> element marks text that has stress emphasis. The <em> element can be nested, with each level of nesting indicating a greater degree of emphasis. MDN web docs: <em>: The Emphasis element
elements.example: In HTML 5, what was previously called block-level content is now called flow content.

elements.headline: figure
elements.description: The HTML <figure> (Figure With Optional Caption) element represents self-contained content, potentially with an optional caption, which is specified using the (<figcaption>) element. The figure, its caption, and its contents are referenced as a single unit. MDN web docs: <figure>: The Figure with Optional Caption element

elements.headline: footer
elements.description: The HTML <footer> element represents a footer for its nearest sectioning content or sectioning root element. A footer typically contains information about the author of the section, copyright data or links to related documents. MDN web docs: <footer>: The Footer element
elements.example: <footer>Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua.</footer>

elements.headline: header
elements.description: The HTML <header> element represents introductory content, typically a group of introductory or navigational aids. It may contain some heading elements but also a logo, a search form, an author name, and other elements. MDN web docs: <header>: The Header element
elements.example: <header>Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua.</header>

elements.headline: h1-h6
elements.description: The HTML <h1>–<h6> elements represent six levels of section headings. <h1> is the highest section level and <h6> is the lowest. MDN web docs: <h1>-<h6>: The HTML Section Heading element
elements.example:
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua.

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua.

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua.

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua.

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua.
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua.

elements.headline: hr
elements.description: The HTML <hr> element represents a thematic break between paragraph-level elements: for example, a change of scene in a story, or a shift of topic within a section. MDN web docs: <hr>: The Thematic Break (Horizontal Rule) element
elements.example:
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua.
<hr>
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua.

elements.headline: i
elements.description: The HTML <i> element represents a range of text that is set off from the normal text for some reason. Some examples include technical terms, foreign language phrases, or fictional character thoughts. It is typically displayed in italic type. MDN web docs: <i>: The Set-off Text element
elements.example: The Latin phrase Veni, vidi, vici is often mentioned in music, art, and literature.

elements.headline: img
elements.description: The HTML <img> element embeds an image into the document. It is a replaced element. MDN web docs: <img>: The Image Embed element

elements.headline: ins
elements.description: The HTML <ins> element represents a range of text that has been added to a document. You can use the <del> element to similarly represent a range of text that has been deleted from the document. MDN web docs: <ins>: The Inserted Text element
elements.example: <ins>This text has been inserted</ins>

elements.headline: kbd
elements.description: The HTML Keyboard Input element (<kbd>) represents a span of inline text denoting textual user input from a keyboard, voice input, or any other text entry device. By convention, the user agent defaults to rendering the contents of a <kbd> element using its default monospace font, although this is not mandated by the HTML standard. MDN web docs: <kbd>: The Keyboard Input element
elements.example: Use the command <kbd>help mycommand</kbd> to view documentation for the command "mycommand".

elements.headline: main
elements.description: The HTML <main> element represents the dominant content of the <body> of a document. The main content area consists of content that is directly related to or expands upon the central topic of a document, or the central functionality of an application. MDN web docs: <main>: The Main sectioning element
elements.example: <main>Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua.</main>

elements.headline: mark
elements.description: The HTML Mark Text element (<mark>) represents text which is marked or highlighted for reference or notation purposes, due to the marked passage's relevance or importance in the enclosing context. MDN web docs: <mark>: The Mark Text element
elements.example: It is a dark time for the Rebellion. Although the Death Star has been destroyed, <mark>Imperial</mark> troops have driven the Rebel forces from their hidden base and pursued them across the galaxy.

elements.headline: meter
elements.description: The HTML <meter> element represents either a scalar value within a known range or a fractional value. MDN web docs: <meter>: The Scalal Value Representation element
elements.example: Heat the oven to 350 degrees.

elements.headline: nav
elements.description: The HTML <nav> element represents a section of a page whose purpose is to provide navigation links, either within the current document or to other documents. Common examples of navigation sections are menus, tables of contents, and indexes. MDN web docs: <nav>: The Navigation Section element
elements.example: <nav>Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua.</nav>

elements.headline: ol
elements.description: The HTML <ol> element represents an ordered list of items, typically rendered as a numbered list. MDN web docs: <ol>: The Ordered List element
elements.example:
1. first item
  2. second item
    1. second item first subitem
    2. second item second subitem
      1. second item second subitem first sub-subitem
      2. second item second subitem second sub-subitem
    3. second item third subitem
  3. third item

elements.headline: output
elements.description: The HTML Output element (<output>) is a container element into which a site or app can inject the results of a calculation or the outcome of a user action. MDN web docs: <output>: The Output element
elements.example:
<form oninput="result.value=parseInt(a.value)+parseInt(b.value)">
	<input type="number" name="b" value="50" /> + 
	<input type="number" name="a" value="10" /> = 
	<output name="result">60</output>
</form>

elements.headline: p
elements.description: The HTML <p> element represents a paragraph. Paragraphs are usually represented in visual media as blocks of text separated from adjacent blocks by blank lines and/or first-line indentation, but HTML paragraphs can be any structural grouping of related content, such as images or form fields. MDN web docs: <p>: The Paragraph element
elements.example:
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua.

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua.

elements.headline: picture
elements.description: The HTML <picture> element contains zero or more <source> elements and one <img> element to provide versions of an image for different display/device scenarios. The browser will consider each child <source> element and choose the best match among them; if no matches are found, the URL of the <img> element's src attribute is selected. The selected image is then presented in the space occupied by the <img> element. MDN web docs: <picture>: The Picture element
elements.example: ​

elements.headline: pre
elements.description: The HTML <pre> element represents preformatted text which is to be presented exactly as written in the HTML file. The text is typically rendered using a non-proportional ("monospace") font. Whitespace inside this element is displayed as written. MDN web docs: <pre>: The Paragraph element
elements.example:
body {
	color:red;
}

elements.headline: progress
elements.description: The HTML <progress> element displays an indicator showing the completion progress of a task, typically displayed as a progress bar. MDN web docs: <progress>: The Progress Indicator element
elements.example: You have completed 70 % of the process.

elements.headline: q
elements.description: The HTML <q> element indicates that the enclosed text is a short inline quotation. Most modern browsers implement this by surrounding the text in quotation marks. This element is intended for short quotations that don't require paragraph breaks; for long quotations use the <blockquote> element. MDN web docs: <q>: The Inline Quotation element
elements.example: According to Mozilla's website, <q cite="https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/about/history/details/">Firefox 1.0 was released in 2004 and became a big success.</q>

elements.headline: s
elements.description: The HTML <s> element renders text with a strikethrough, or a line through it. Use the <s> element to represent things that are no longer relevant or no longer accurate. However, <s> is not appropriate when indicating document edits; for that, use the <del> and <ins> elements, as appropriate. MDN web docs: <s>: The Strikethrough element
elements.example: <s>Today's Special: Salmon</s> SOLD OUT

elements.headline: samp
elements.description: The HTML Sample Element (<samp>) is used to enclose inline text which represents sample (or quoted) output from a computer program. Its contents are typically rendered using the browser's default monospaced font (such as Courier or Lucida Console). MDN web docs: <samp>: The Sample Output element
elements.example: When the process is complete, the utility will output the text Scan complete. Found N results. You can then proceed to the next step.

elements.headline: section
elements.description: The HTML <section> element represents a standalone section — which doesn't have a more specific semantic element to represent it — contained within an HTML document. Typically, but not always, sections have a heading. MDN web docs: <section>: The Generic Section element
elements.example: <section>Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua.</section>

elements.headline: select
elements.description: The HTML <select> element represents a control that provides a menu of options MDN web docs: <select>: The Selectbox element

elements.headline: small
elements.description: The HTML <small> element makes the text font size one size smaller (for example, from large to medium, or from small to x-small) down to the browser's minimum font size.  In HTML5, this element is repurposed to represent side-comments and small print, including copyright and legal text, independent of its styled presentation. MDN web docs: <small>: The Small element
elements.example: This is the first sentence. <small>This whole sentence is in small letters.</small>

elements.headline: span
elements.description: The HTML <span> element is a generic inline container for phrasing content, which does not inherently represent anything. It can be used to group elements for styling purposes (using the class or id attributes), or because they share attribute values, such as lang. It should be used only when no other semantic element is appropriate. <span> is very much like a <div> element, but <div> is a block-level element whereas a <span> is an inline element. MDN web docs: <span>: The Small element
elements.example: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua.

elements.headline: strong
elements.description: The HTML Strong Importance Element (<strong>) indicates that its contents have strong importance, seriousness, or urgency. Browsers typically render the contents in bold type. MDN web docs: <strong>: The Small element
elements.example: Before proceeding, make sure you put on your safety goggles.

elements.headline: sub
elements.description: The HTML Subscript element (<sub>) specifies inline text which should be displayed as subscript for solely typographical reasons. Subscripts are typically rendered with a lowered baseline using smaller text. MDN web docs: <sub>: The Subscript element
elements.example: Almost every developer's favorite molecule is C<sub>8</sub>H<sub>10</sub>N<sub>4</sub>O<sub>2</sub>, which is commonly known as "caffeine."

elements.headline: sup
elements.description: The HTML Superscript element (<sup>) specifies inline text which is to be displayed as superscript for solely typographical reasons. Superscripts are usually rendered with a raised baseline using smaller text. MDN web docs: <sup>: The Superscript element
elements.example: One of the most common equations in all of physics is <var>E</var>=<var>m</var><var>c</var><sup>2</sup>.

elements.headline: table
elements.description: The HTML <table> element represents tabular data — that is, information presented in a two-dimensional table comprised of rows and columns of cells containing data. MDN web docs: <table>: The Table element
elements.example:
Table caption
Lime Lemon Orange
Green Yellow Orange

elements.headline: textarea
elements.description: The HTML <textarea> element represents a multi-line plain-text editing control, useful when you want to allow users to enter a sizeable amount of free-form text, for example a comment on a review or feedback form. MDN web docs: <textarea>: The Textarea element

elements.headline: time
elements.description: The HTML <time> element represents a specific period in time. It may include the datetime attribute to translate dates into machine-readable format, allowing for better search engine results or custom features such as reminders. MDN web docs: <time>: The Time element
elements.example: The concert starts at <time datetime="2018-07-07T20:00:00">20:00</time>.

elements.headline: u
elements.description: The HTML Unarticulated Annotation Element (<u>) represents a span of inline text which should be rendered in a way that indicates that it has a non-textual annotation. This is rendered by default as a simple solid underline, but may be altered using CSS. MDN web docs: <u>: The Unarticulated Annotation (Underline) element
elements.example: This paragraph includes a <u class="spelling">wrnogly</u> spelled word.

elements.headline: ul
elements.description: The HTML <ul> element represents an unordered list of items, typically rendered as a bulleted list. MDN web docs: <ul>: The Unordered List element
elements.example:
• first item
  • second item
    • second item first subitem
    • second item second subitem
      • second item second subitem first sub-subitem
      • second item second subitem second sub-subitem
    • second item third subitem
  • third item

elements.headline: var
elements.description: The HTML Variable element (<var>) represents the name of a variable in a mathematical expression or a programming context. It's typically presented using an italicized version of the current typeface, although that behavior is browser-dependent. MDN web docs: <var>: The Variable element
elements.example: A simple equation: <var>x</var> = <var>y</var> + 2

elements.headline: video
elements.description: The HTML Video element (<video>) embeds a media player which supports video playback into the document. You can use <video> for audio content as well, but the <audio> element may provide a more appropriate user experience. MDN web docs: <video>: The Video Embed element

elements.headline: wbr
elements.description: The HTML <wbr> element represents a word break opportunity—a position within text where the browser may optionally break a line, though its line-breaking rules would not otherwise create a break at that location. MDN web docs: <wbr>: The Word Break Opportunity element
elements.example: http://this<wbr>.is<wbr>.a<wbr>.really<wbr>.long<wbr>.example<wbr>.com/With<wbr>/deeper<wbr>/level<wbr>/pages<wbr>/deeper<wbr>/level<wbr>/pages<wbr>/deeper<wbr>/level<wbr>/pages<wbr>/deeper<wbr>/level<wbr>/pages<wbr>/deeper<wbr>/level<wbr>/pages
